block.p: At Least 6 Sailors Die In U.S. Warship Blast The destroyer Cole was rocked by an enormous explosion while refueling in Yemen, in what President Clinton said appeared to be a deliberate attack. Senior Pentagon officials said the explosion came from a small harbor boat that had been loaded with explosives in a well-planned suicide attack. At least 6 sailors died, 11 others were missing and presumed dead and dozens were wounded.
Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush each said the United States should take steps to find and punish those responsible.

At Least 6 Sailors Die In U.S. Warship Blast The destroyer Cole was rocked by an enormous explosion while refueling in Yemen, in what President Clinton said appeared to be a deliberate attack. Senior Pentagon officials said the explosion came from a small harbor boat that had been loaded with explosives in a well-planned suicide attack. At least 6 sailors died, 11 others were missing and presumed dead and dozens were wounded.
Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush each said the United States should take steps to find and punish those responsible.
The sailors were casualties of a recent military strategy to help strengthen Yemen's government through frequent Navy port calls.
More than 100 spouses and children waited together at the Norfolk Naval Base for official word on who perished and who survived.

Mideast Violence Intensifies Israeli helicopter gunships rocketed Ramallah and Gaza City after a Palestinian mob stabbed and stomped to death two Israeli reserve soldiers and then paraded a mutilated body in the street. Blaming the killings squarely on the Palestinian Authority, Israelis described the response as ''limited'' and ''symbolic.''

President Clinton failed to get Israeli and Palestinian leaders to commit themselves publicly to ending the violence. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt offered to convene a meeting that would include Mr. Clinton, Israel, the Palestinians and Jordan.
Israelis of all political persuasions appeared united in revulsion at the mob killing of their soldiers but divided over what should be done.
Leaders across the Arab world braced for demonstrations after morning mosque prayers today.

Americans Seized in Ecuador Members of the largest guerrilla group in Colombia kidnapped five American and five other foreign oil workers in the Amazon region of Ecuador and hijacked a helicopter to take them back across the border to territory they control, the Ecuadorean government said.
Chinese Writer Gets Nobel Gao Xingjian, a novelist and playwright whose works have been banned by China since the late 1980's, received the Nobel Prize in Literature. Mr. Gao, 60, lives in France.

Bush Camp Hails Debate; Gore Hits at Texas Record The candidates campaigned in swing states. Vice President Al Gore pressed his attack on George W. Bush's record as governor of Texas, and the Bush campaign exulted in what it saw as a pivotal moment in the race -- Wednesday's debate.
The Bush campaign sparred with the Gore campaign and advocates of hate crime legislation over a Texas hate crime bill and Mr. Bush's misstatement regarding one case.
Mr. Bush's accusation in the debate that I.M.F. aid money had lined the pockets of former Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia was rejected by the fund and by Mr. Chernomyrdin.

Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, visiting Odessa, Tex., to drive home the Democrats' charge that Mr. Bush would pose an environmental threat as president, listened to residents tell of foul-smelling air and water and fear that their health problems are tied to nearby industrial plants.
Some House Democrats were disappointed with Mr. Gore's debate performance and expressed concern about his ability to help Democrats regain control of the House.
About 37.6 million people watched the debate, the second-smallest television audience ever, after the second debate between President Clinton and Bob Dole in 1996.

Action on Budget Measures The Senate approved four of nine remaining spending bills needed to keep the government running, setting the stage for lawmakers and the White House to focus on the most contentious measures next week.
Military Retiree Health Care Congress approved permanent health care coverage for all retired career military personnel, at cost of $60 billion over the next decade.
Bankruptcy Bill Veto Pledged The White House said President Clinton would veto a measure, which sailed through the House, that would overhaul the bankruptcy system.

Penalties for Disclosure Congress voted to expand government authority to bring criminal charges against people who disclose classified data. The president is expected to sign the bill, which makes almost all unauthorized and willful disclosures of classified data by government employees a felony carrying up to three years in prison.

White House Visitors Were Asked for Donations The Senate campaign of Hillary Rodham Clinton solicited contributions last month from 1,400 people whose names were obtained from an official list of White House visitors. The campaign said Mrs. Clinton had played a role in the transfer of the names, but asserted that what had happened was accidental.

Designer for Times Skyscraper The New York Times chose a design by Renzo Piano, an Italian architect who gained recognition 23 years ago for the Centre Pompidou in Paris, for the newspaper's planned new headquarters on Eighth Avenue.

2nd New Jersey Senate Debate Representative Bob Franks, the Republican candidate, kept Jon S. Corzine, the Democrat, on the defensive, accusing him of trying to buy the election and of advocating costly big-government spending programs.
Mets Lead Series, 2-0 New York beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 6-5, in the Game 2 of the National League Championship Series.
Poor Showing on Math Test More than three-quarters of New York City's eighth graders failed to reach acceptable levels on a statewide math test last spring.

Gift for Gay Campus Center A gay couple gave $2 million for a new gay and lesbian student center at the University of Pennsylvania, where the men met as students. The donation is apparently the largest gift from gay alumni to benefit a campus lesbian and gay group.

A Piece of Frozen Space Pieces of a meteorite that fell over a frozen Canadian lake in January appear to be the oldest and most pristine extraterrestrial material yet found, geologists say, and may carry clues about the early solar system and the origin of life on Earth.

Stock Markets Tumble The Dow plunged 379.21 points, or 3.6 percent, to 10,034.58, its lowest level since March. The Nasdaq lost 93.81 points, or 3 percent, closing at 3,074.68, its lowest point for the year. The S.& P. 500 fell 34.81 points, or 2.6 percent, to 1,329.78.
Fear Pushes Oil Prices Higher The price of crude oil surged $2.81 a barrel, or more than 8 percent, to $36.06, on fear that Middle East violence could disrupt the flow of oil.

Shake-Up at WebMD Jim Clark resigned from the board of WebMD, and Jeff Arnold resigned as co-chief executive. WebMD, which links health care professionals, has been losing more than $80 million every three months. Martin J. Wygod took full control as the remaining chief executive.

China to Make U.S. Abortion Pill An official of Hualian Pharmaceutical said its factory near Shanghai would soon begin exporting to the United States RU-486, the abortion pill newly approved by the F.D.A. The agency has not identified the manufacturer because of opposition to the bill by abortion opponents.
